block.p: Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''THE LAND OF SMILES,'' a musical with rod and hand puppets by the puppeteer and singer Susan Delery Whedon, with characters like Griti the Gremlin. Saturdays and Sundays at noon and 1:30 p.m. Through Aug. 27. Papageno Puppet Theater, 462 Columbus Avenue, near 82nd Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $6. Reservations required: (212) 874-3297.

''ROMEO AND JULIET,'' a 90-minute production featuring masks, music and pageantry by the Lite Theater Company staged amid the open-air classical architecture of steps and columns at the Tennis House in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. (Enter the park at Ninth Street and Prospect Park Drive and cross the West Drive.) Audience members may bring blankets or folding chairs. For all ages. Saturdays at 4 p.m. and Sundays and Wednesdays at 7 p.m. Through Aug. 19. Free. Information: (212) 414-7773.

''THE UGLY DUCKLING,'' a musical version of the fairy tale by Debra Kaye, with lyrics by Brenda Bell, by Literally Alive at the Hitchcock-Rockefeller Auditorium, Y.W.C.A., Lexington Avenue at 53rd Street, Manhattan. For ages 3 to 8. Today at 11 a.m. (art workshop, to create decorations for the stage, at 10 a.m.); tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m., with the art workshop at 1. Tickets: $15 (summer special, two tickets for the price of one); $5 workshop fee. Group rates for 20 and more. Reservations: (212) 866-5170.
Events

''THE ADVENTURES OF ROCKY AND BULLWINKLE AND FRIENDS,'' selections from works by the television animator Jay Ward, through Sept. 17 at the Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Screenings are Tuesdays through Sundays at 12:15 p.m., with additional screenings Thursdays at 6 p.m. and Fridays at 7 p.m. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 13 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

AIKIDO TECHNIQUES DEMONSTRATION. Students from the Aikido School of Self Defense will demonstate the technique tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. at the Douglaston/Little Neck Branch of the Queens Borough Library, 249-01 Northern Boulevard, Little Neck. For teenagers. Preregistration is required. (718) 225-8414. Free.

ANDES MANTA, a troupe playing music from the Andes on more than 35 traditional instruments, which children will learn about and try to play, is to perform tomorrow at 2 p.m. as part of the AT&T Latino Arts Festival at Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, off Exit 9E of the Grand Central Parkway, near Shea Stadium. Free. Information: (718) 760-0064.

''BEADS, BODY AND SOUL: ART AND LIGHT IN THE YORUBA UNIVERSE,'' an exhibition presented jointly by the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street (through Sept. 17), and the Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston, SoHo (through Aug. 27), explores 1,000 years of beaded arts in Yoruba culture. The Museum for African Art will present a workshop tomorrow at 1 p.m. on how to create artworks using abstract symbols, colors and precious objects that have a symbolic power. Limited to 30 children 5 and older. Free with museum admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly. Call to reserve space for all activities. Information: (212) 966-1313, extension 125.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY. Two workshops tomorrow from 1 to 2:30 p.m. Searching for invertebrates and insects in the North Woods with Michael Russo, an artist and naturalist, at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue, (212) 860-1370. For ages 6 and older. Also, watercolor painting at Turtle Pond for children 8 and older, at the Henry Luce Observatory at Belvedere Castle, mid-park at 79th Street, (212) 772-0210. Free.

''FISH JUBILEE.'' Activities focused on the marine life in the Hudson River. Wednesdays through Sundays from noon to 5 p.m. throughout August. There is big-city fishing, with rod, reel and bait (all provided free) and workshops to learn about the Hudson River's ecosystem using microscopes to take a closer look. Piers 25, at North Moore Street, and 40, at Houston Street. Free. Information: (212) 533-7275.

GROUP HEALTH INCORPORATED BRONX TENNIS CLASSIC, in Crotona Park, the Bronx, tomorrow through Aug. 20. Free group tennis lessons (open to adults and children) will be offered daily, with USA Tennis pros from the New York Junior Tennis League, who will teach the basics of the game each day from 11 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. In addition to the free lessons, professional singles and doubles matches will be played on the courts of Crotona Park during the week; admission is free. During the final weekend of the event, next Friday to Aug. 20, there will be events for youngsters, including a parade (Thursday from 11 a.m. to noon), pony express rodeo events (on the north baseball field for $8 a person), competitions and clinics. Information: (718) 786-7110, Extension 65.

MAKE A CRAB PUPPET. Youngsters will meet tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. at the Children's Center, South Street Seaport Museum, 165 John Street, South and Fulton Streets, Lower Manhattan, and then visit the Peking's Wet Lab, moored outside the museum, for a workshop where they can create a horseshoe crab puppet to take home. $3 materials fee. Information: (212) 748-8600.

''MAGIC WORKSHOP.'' David and Dorothy, a brother and sister duo, will perform and demonstrate magic tricks, tomorrow at 3 p.m. Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 621-0618 or (212) 621-0636. For ages 6 to 12. Free.

''PASSING ON THE TRADITION 2000,'' an annual event featuring workshops, symposiums, lecture-demonstrations, discussions and performances focusing on passing on the heritage of global carnival and masquerade. Tomorrow from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. there will be free workshops in dance, steel-pan drum, calypso, history and culture, along with performances by the Rio Samba Band and Tobago Heritage Festival Performers. The event culminates in ''Youth Pan Festival 2000,'' a steel-pan music festival for virtuosos of the pan under 21 years and guest artists, with the music including reggae, classical, jazz, calypso and soca, tomorrow from 6 to 10 p.m., at the Medgar Evers College, 1650 Bedford Avenue, between Crown and Montgomery Streets, Brooklyn. There will be prizes for various age divisions, and for the first time an ensemble category has been added for groups of 4 to 10 players. Information: (718) 951-3645. Free.

''STORY CORNER: MADCAP ADVENTURES.'' Children will learn about some of the adventures behind the scenes of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, tomorrow at 4 p.m. in the American Paintings galleries on the fifth floor, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.

''WHISPERS FROM THE WILD STORYTELLING.'' Youngsters can settle into the cool shade beside the wetlands of the Everett Children's Adventure Garden of the New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, Bedford Park, the Bronx, tomorrow and Sunday (also Sept. 9 and 10) at 2 p.m. and listen to storytellers in an ideal setting. Tomorrow, Nilda Garces and the Garces Puppets will perform; on Sunday, Jonathan Kruk will engage children with audience participation and animal folk tales. Children can check out other activities, including three mazes and the Summer Train Show. Adventure garden admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; children 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are combination packages. Parking: $5. Information: (718) 817-8700.
Exhibitions

''LIVING ON THE EDGE,'' an interactive exhibition about the coastal environment, the edge between land and sea, through Aug. 26 at the Queens Library Gallery inside Queens Borough Public Library's Central Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica. Visitors may activate a 10-foot-long wave tank, design a coastal landscape by computer, alter water currents with their hands and test their survival skills as a creature of ''the edge'' (lobster, flounder or plankton). Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Information: (718) 990-8665. Free.

''SEUSS!'' An interactive exhibition featuring the characters of Dr. Seuss, especially the Cat in the Hat, through Labor Day at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, 212 West 83rd Street. Museum hours through Labor Day: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free with museum admission: $6; infants under 1, free. Information: (212) 721-1234.
Zoos

ZOO VET. Youngsters can learn about life as a zoo veterinarian with Dr. Frank Borzio, who will talk about his behind-the-scenes adventures. Sunday at 2 p.m. at the Staten Island Zoo, 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton. Zoo attractions include a rain forest; the African Savanna at Twilight, with leopards, baboons and antelopes; and a petting zoo. Free with zoo admission; preregistration required, (718) 442-3174 or (718) 442-3101. Admission: $3; children 3 to 11, $2; under 3, free.
